questions.text: Mutation in which of the following genes causes Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Wilson's disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. It an autosomal recessive condition.

The ATP7B gene is located on chromosome 13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

The resulting ATP7B deficiency leads to reduced bound copper and impaired free copper excretion. This causes excess deposition of free copper in the tissues, particularly in the liver, brain and eye.

Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive condition leading to impaired absorption of copper and subsequent copper deficiency. Here, the mutation is in the ATP7A gene.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with tremors and chronic hepatitis is found to have the following ophthalmic finding. This patient is also likely to have which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring. This,along with the background of hepatitis and neuropsychiatric features is characteristic of Wilson's disease. The patient is thus likely to have basal ganglia atrophy.

In the majority of cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia and cortex. Free copper deposition in the basal ganglia leads to bilateral degeneration and atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following would you use to screen an asymptomatic sibling of a patient with Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Genetic testing for the ATP7B gene is used to screen asymptomatic 1st and 2nd-degree relatives of patients with Wilson's disease. This helps to differentiate the heterozygous from the homozygous individuals. This can be useful in the early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and Kayser-Fleischer rings are diagnostically helpful.

Estimation of hepatic tissue copper is the gold standard for diagnosis. It is measured using neutron activation analysis / atomic absorption spectrometry.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with personality changes and jaundice. Slit-lamp examination confirmed the diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Ceruloplasmin in blood increases and urinary copper excretion decreases
Ceruloplasmin in blood decreases and urinary copper excretion decreases
Ceruloplasmin in blood increases and urinary copper excretion increases
Ceruloplasmin in blood decreases and urinary copper excretion increases

questions.solution:
The ceruloplasmin level in the blood decreases, and the copper content in urine increases in Wilson's disease.

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine

questions.text: Which of the following stains can be used to demonstrate excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease is demonstrated by rhodanine stain.

Microscopic findings in Wilson's disease include:

  • Fatty infiltration (macrovesicular)
  • Glycogen deposition in periportal hepatocytes
  • Macronodular cirrhosis in decompensated stages. 

Orcein stain is used to stain copper-associated proteins (eg: ceruloplasmin).

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis.

The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue.

The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: A patient with hereditary hemochromatosis is found to have a mutation in the HFE gene. On which chromosome is it located?
questions.solution:
HFE gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (6p). It is the most commonly mutated gene in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis.

HFE encodes an HLA class I–like molecule that regulates the synthesis of hepcidin in hepatocytes. The most common HFE mutation is a cysteine-to-tyrosine substitution at amino acid 282 (C282Y).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man evaluated for chronic abdominal pain is found to have hepatomegaly and serum ferritin level of 1800 micro g/l. Which of the following complications is he at the greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. A patient with hemochromatosis is at risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.

Hepatocellular carcinoma is a significant cause of death in hemochromatosis. The risk is much greater than in the general population.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding hemochromatosis?
  1. Neonatal hemochromatosis is not an inherited disease.
  2. Adult hemochromatosis is generally a milder disease than juvenile form.
  3. The skin pigmentation is due to excessive hemosiderin deposition.
  4. Bantu siderosis is due to dietary iron overload.
  5. Total iron accumulation in severe cases exceeds 25 gm.
questions.solution:
Neonatal hemochromatosis is not an inherited disease. It is a disease of unknown origin manifested by severe liver disease and extrahepatic hemosiderin deposition. It might be related to maternal alloimmune injury to the fetal liver.
 
Adult hemochromatosis is generally a milder disease than the juvenile form. With treatment, life expectancy is normal.
 
Bantu siderosis or African iron overload is due to dietary iron overload. Consumption of beer prepared in iron pots or drums is the cause of dietary iron overload.
 
Skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis mostly results from increased melanin synthesis. This is due to iron deposition and not hemosiderin deposition.
 
In severe hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm. More than one-third of this accumulates in the liver. In normal adults, it is in the range of 2 to 6 gms.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis.

Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic.

Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity:

  1. Liver
  2. Pancreas
  3. Myocardium
  4. Pituitary gland
  5. Adrenal gland
  6. Thyroid
  7. Parathyroid gland
  8. Joints
  9. Skin

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. α1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.

The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are characteristic of this disease.

questions.text: On which chromosome is the gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin present?
questions.solution:
The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes.

For α1-antitrypsin genes, the general notation is “Pi” for “protease inhibitor." An alphabetic letter is given for the position on the isoelectric gel.

This gene has different alleles that produce different amounts of alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT).

  • M allele - normal levels of the AAT protein
  • S allele - moderately low levels
  • Z allele - very low levels

The alleles are expressed in a codominant manner.

questions.text: What is the most common clinically significant mutation causing alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency?
questions.solution:
The most common clinically significant mutation causing α1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZ. Homozygous individuals, with PiZZ, have only 10% of normal circulating α1-antitrypsin. So, they are at high risk of developing clinical disease.

PiMM is the most common genotype seen in normal individuals, present in about 90% of individuals.

PiS variant is clinically asymptomatic.

Pi-null is a rare variant with no detectable serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl with persistently elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) has been diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis. Which of the following pathological features would you not expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon in autoimmune hepatitis except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:

  • Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
  • Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.
  • Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis with lymphoplasmacytic interface hepatitis.

A small number of drugs such as minocycline, nitrofurantoin, and α-methyldopa can trigger the formation of autoantibodies and hepatocellular injury that mimics autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with regard to autoimmune hepatitis?

choices.text: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows antinuclear antibodies (ANA).
It can progress to liver failure.
Inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of plasma cells.

questions.solution:
Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-liver kidney microsomal autoantibodies (anti-LKM1) and anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies not ANA.

Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-nuclear (ANA), anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) and anti–soluble liver antigen / liver pancreas antigen (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies. It less commonly shows anti-mitochondrial (AMA) antibodies.

Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by continuing hepatocellular necrosis and inflammation. It can progress to cirrhosis and liver failure.

Histocompatibility haplotypes such as HLA-B1, HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, and HLA-DR4 are common in patients with autoimmune hepatitis.

Histopathological features include:

  • Plasma cell predominance in inflammatory infiltrates
  • Extensive interface hepatitis (piecemeal necrosis) 
  • Hepatocyte rosettes 

The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis showing characteristic lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and interface hepatitis.

questions.solution:
Anti-TIF1γ antibodies are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-TIF1γ antibodies are found in patients with dermatomyositis.

questions.text: The histopathological findings obtained after a liver biopsy is given below. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Onion-skin fibrosis is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

The smaller ducts in primary sclerosing cholangitis show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen. This eventually leads to the obliteration by a “tombstone” scar.

The image shows primary sclerosing cholangitis. There is a degenerating bile duct that is entrapped in the dense concentric onion-skin fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Onion Skin Appearance in Pathology

Onion skin appearance:

A pattern characterised by concentric laminations of differing radiologic or histologic densities. It is seen in:

  1. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: Onion skin fibrosis
  2. Castleman disease: Onion skin appearance of Mantle zone lymphocytes
  3. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Onion skin lesions in spleen
  4. Thrombotic thrombocytopenia purpura (TTP): Onion skinning of renal arteries and arterioles
  5. Ewing sarcoma: Laminated periosteal reaction (onion skin)
  6. Malignant hypertension: Onion skin lesion/ Hyperplastic arteriolitis
  7. Tay–Sach's disease: Whorled arrangement (onion skin) of cytoplasmic inclusions within lysosomes of ganglion cells under electron microscopy
  8. Lyme arthritis: Onion skin thickening of the arterial wall
  9. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease: Onion bulb formation of proliferated Schwann cells around the axon due to recurrent demyelination and remyelination

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. There is dilation of preserved segments.

On histopathologic examination, large ducts show acute neutrophilic inflammation of the epithelium. The inflamed areas develop strictures. Small ducts show onion-skin fibrosis around the atrophic duct lumen. There is an obliteration of ducts by a tombstone scar.

questions.text: Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with Sjogren's syndrome. Other associated conditions are:

  • Thyroiditis 
  • Scleroderma
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Celiac disease

PBC is an autoimmune disease. It is characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved. It is a disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1. Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.

Histopathologic examination shows diagnostic florid duct lesions. These are lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates with or without granulomas centred around the bile duct. They also show Mallory–Denk bodies.
